raw_text:
S Korea spending boost to economy
 
 South Korea will boost state spending next year in an effort to create jobs and kick start its sputtering economy.
 
 It has earmarked 100 trillion won ($96bn) for the first six months of 2005, 60% of its total annual budget. The government's main problems are "slumping consumption and a contraction in the construction industry". It aims to create 400,000 jobs and will focus on infrastructure and home building, as well as providing public firms with money to hire new workers.
 
 The government has set an economic growth rate target of 5% for next year and hinted that would be in danger unless it took action. "Internal and external economic conditions are likely to remain unfavourable in 2005," the Finance and Economy Ministry said in a statement.
 
 It blamed "continuing uncertainties such as fluctuating oil prices and foreign exchange rates and stagnant domestic demand that has shown few signs of a quick rebound". In 2004, growth will be between 4.7% and 4.8%, the ministry said. Not everyone is convinced the plan will work. "Our primary worry centres on the what we believe is the government's overly optimistic view that its front loading of the budget will be enough to turn the economy around," consultancy 4Cast said in a report.
 
 The problem facing South Korea is that many consumers are reeling from the effects of a credit bubble that only recently burst. Millions of South Koreans are defaulting on their credit card bills, and the country's biggest card lender has been hovering on the verge of bankruptcy for months. As part of its spending plans, the government said it will ask firms to "roll over mortgage loans that come due in the first half of 2005" . It also pledged to look at ways of helping families on low incomes.
 
 The government voiced concern about the effect of redundancies in the building trade. "Given the economic spill over and employment effect in the construction sector, a sharp downturn in the construction industry could have other adverse effects," the ministry said.
 
 As a result, South Korea will give private companies also will be given the chance to build schools, hospitals, houses and other public buildings. It also will look at real estate tax system. Other plans on the table include promoting new industries such as bio-technology and nano-technology, as well as offering increased support to small and medium sized businesses. "The focus will be on job creation and economic recovery, given that unfavourable domestic and global conditions are likely to dog the Korean economy in 2005," the ministry said.
llama3.2:1b: South Korea is spending 100 trillion won ($96bn) next year to boost its economy, with a main goal of creating jobs and kicking-starting its slumping economy.
The government aims to create 400,000 jobs through infrastructure development and public firm hiring, while also focusing on providing money to private companies for new hires.
llama3.2:3b: South Korea to boost state spending by 100 trillion won ($96bn) for 2005 to create jobs and kickstart its economy, aiming to achieve a 5% growth rate target, amid "continuing uncertainties" such as fluctuating oil prices and stagnant domestic demand.

The government plans to focus on infrastructure, home building, and hiring new workers, while also providing support to small and medium-sized businesses, and looking at ways to help families on low incomes.
gemma2:2b: South Korea will spend $96 billion in the first six months of 2005 to boost its sputtering economy by creating jobs, funding infrastructure, and supporting public firms.
This spending is part of a plan to achieve a 5% economic growth rate target for next year.
The government acknowledges concerns about consumer debt and stagnant demand, but aims to leverage increased state spending and support for private projects to stimulate the economy.
However, some experts are skeptical about its effectiveness.
qwen2.5:0.5b: South Korea plans to boost state spending next year to create jobs and kick-start its economy, with a goal of 400, 000 new jobs expected.
The government aims to focus on infrastructure and home building, as well as providing money for public firms to hire workers.

The Ministry of Finance is concerned about the "slumping consumption" and "contraction in the construction industry", while critics suggest the plan could be ineffective due to ongoing uncertainties such as oil prices and foreign exchange rates, and poor domestic demand that has not shown a quick rebound.
The government will aim to turn the economy around by focusing on job creation and economic recovery.
qwen2.5:1.5b: South Korea plans to boost state spending by 100 trillion won ($96bn) over the first six months of 2005 to create jobs and stimulate its struggling economy, aiming for a growth rate target of 5% in the coming year despite ongoing uncertainties such as fluctuating oil prices, foreign exchange rates, and stagnant domestic demand.
qwen2.5:3b: South Korea plans to boost state spending by 100 trillion won ($96bn) for the first half of 2005, aiming to create 400,000 jobs through infrastructure and home building projects, as well as aiding public firms and hiring new workers.
The government aims for a 5% economic growth rate but faces challenges including weak domestic demand and unstable oil prices.

To tackle these issues, it will extend mortgage loans, offer support to low-income families, promote industries like bio-technology and nano-technology, and encourage small and medium-sized businesses.
However, some experts doubt the plan's effectiveness.
opencoder:1.5b:
S Korea spending boost to economy

South Korea is set to boost state spending in response to creating jobs and kickingstart its sputtering economy.
The government has earmarked 100 trillion won ($96bn) for the first six months of 2005, a portion of its total annual budget.
The main problems are "slumping consumption and a contraction in the construction industry."
The government aims to create 400,000 jobs and is focused on infrastructure and home building, as well as providing public firms with money to hire new workers.
The economy's economic growth rate target is set at 5% for next year and hinted that it might be in danger unless further action is taken.
The government has stated an optimistic view of the future growth which will remain unfavourable in 2005.
"Internal and external economic conditions are likely to remain unfavourable in 2005," the ministry said.
The plan focuses primarily on a credit bubble, affecting hundreds of South Korean businesses.
As part of its spending plans, government promises to ask firms to "roll over mortgage loans that come due in the first half of 2005."
The government is also concerned about the effect of redundancies in the building trade, as it could cause a sharp downturn in the construction industry.
The country's biggest card lender has been struggling for months, impacting several businesses and leading to a job loss.
In conclusion, South Korea will likely face major challenges such as a credit crunch, reduced employment opportunities, and a decline in economic growth from the job market.
The government's strategy is to create jobs, recover its economy, and promote new industries.
smollm:1.7b: South Korea's spending boost is designed to create jobs and kick-start its economy, but it faces several challenges.
The country's main problems are "slumping consumption and a contraction in the construction industry", which will limit its ability to create jobs.
Additionally, South Korea has set an economic growth rate target of 5% for next year, which is unlikely to be met unless it takes action.
The government blamed "continuing uncertainties such as fluctuating oil prices and stagnant domestic demand" for the slowdown in economic growth.
It also acknowledged that its primary worry is the economy's ability to recover from a credit bubble that burst last year.
The government has set an ambitious target of 5% economic growth, but it faces significant challenges if it fails to meet this goal.
South Korea's spending boost will focus on infrastructure and home building, as well as providing public firms with money to hire new workers.
However, the country still faces several challenges that could limit its ability to create jobs.
For example, the government's plan to give private companies more time to build schools, hospitals and other public buildings may not be enough to meet demand in these areas.
Additionally, South Korea has set a target of 400,000 jobs for next year, which is unlikely to be met unless it takes action to support small and medium-sized businesses.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: South Korea aims to spend $100 trillion won over six months in 2005 to boost its economy and create jobs.

The government targets a 5% annual growth rate for the next year but is concerned about unfavourable conditions, particularly from consumer spending due to a credit bubble and a sluggish housing market.
To stimulate demand, the government plans to provide additional funding for builders, focus on infrastructure development, and help families with low-income needs.
Initiatives include supporting businesses in new industries like bio-technology and nano-technology, as well as promoting public buildings like schools and hospitals.
tinyllama:1.1b: South Korea plans to boost state spending by 100 trillion won ($96 billion) for the first six months of 2005, as it seeks to create jobs and kick-start its struggling economy.
The government will allocate 400,000 jobs through infra-structure and home building efforts aimed at creating 400,000 new jobs in the second half of the year.

The country's main problems are slumping consumer confidence and a contraction in the construction industry, which has led to the government looking for ways to help families on low income and struggling businesses.

South Korea also plans to look at measures aimed at promoting new industries such as bio-technology and nanotechnology, along with increasing real estate tax support for small and medium size businesses.
The government aims to create 400,000 jobs by boosting state spending in an effort to provide public firms with the money they need to hire new workers.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The South Korean government plans to boost state spending next year as part of its effort to create jobs and kick start their struggling economy.
The plan includes allocating 100 trillion won ($96 billion) for the first six months of 2005, and a total of 60% of its annual budget.
This is in an attempt to kickstart economic growth that has been affected by fluctuations in oil prices and foreign exchange rates.
The government hopes that its stimulus measures will create 400,000 jobs and provide public sector firms with the necessary funding to hire new workers.
South Korea's current economic growth rate is expected to remain at around 5%, but a slowdown in domestic demand has shown no signs of resuming.
phi:2.7b: South Korea plans to spend 100 trillion won ($96 billion) next year to create jobs and boost its sputtering economy, earmarked for the first six months of 2005, accounting for 60% of total annual budget.
The government aims to create 400,000 jobs by focusing on infrastructure, home building, public firms hiring new workers with funding.
However, there is concern that the plan may not work due to continuing economic uncertainties, and many consumers are still reeling from the credit bubble's effects.
orca-mini:3b: South Korea is planning to increase its government spending by 100 trillion won ($96bn) for the first six months of 2005, which is 60% of its total annual budget.
The government aims to create 400,000 jobs and is focusing on infrastructure and home building, as well as public firms receiving money to hire new workers.
However, many South Koreans are reeling from the effects of a credit bubble and the country's biggest card lender has been hovering on the verge of bankruptcy for months.

The government will ask firms to "roll over mortgage loans that come due in the first half of 2005" and is also planning to promote new industries such as bio-technology and nano-technology, as well as offer increased support to small and medium sized businesses.
hermes3:3b: S Korea increasing state spending by 100tr W ($96bn) for 1st half of 2005 to create jobs & boost economy, aiming for 5% growth next year.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: South Korea plans to increase state spending next year in an effort to create jobs and boost its struggling economy.
The government has earmarked 100 trillion won ($96bn) for the first six months of 2005, representing 60% of its total annual budget.
It aims to create 400,000 jobs and will focus on infrastructure, home building, and providing public firms with money to hire new workers.
To address issues such as slumping consumption and a contraction in the construction industry, the government has set an economic growth rate target of 5%.
In 2004, growth is expected to be between 4.7% and 4.8%.
Critics argue that the plan may not work due to ongoing uncertainties, including fluctuating oil prices and foreign exchange rates, as well as stagnant domestic demand.
The South Korean government will also ask firms to roll over mortgage loans that come due in the first half of 2005 and explore ways to support families on low incomes.

Furthermore, the government plans to promote new industries such as bio-technology and nano-technology and provide increased support to small and medium-sized businesses, with a focus on job creation and economic recovery amid unfavorable domestic and global conditions.
chatgpt-4o-latest: South Korea will increase state spending in 2005 to stimulate its struggling economy and create 400,000 jobs, allocating 100 trillion won ($96bn) in the first half of the year.
The government aims to boost infrastructure, home building, and public sector hiring while targeting 5% economic growth.
Challenges include weak domestic demand, fluctuating oil prices, and a struggling construction industry.
Consumer debt remains a major issue, with many defaulting on credit card payments.
The government plans to support low-income families, encourage mortgage loan extensions, and allow private firms to build public infrastructure.
Additional measures include promoting biotechnology and nanotechnology and supporting small businesses.
However, some analysts doubt the effectiveness of the plan, warning that budget front-loading may not be enough to revive the economy.
stablelm2:1.6b: South Korea plans to increase state spending for the first half of 2025 as part of its efforts to revive the struggling economy, with an investment of ₩1 trillion ($89.7 billion).
The plan aims to create jobs and focus on infrastructure and home building.
It will also provide money for public firms to hire new workers.

South Korea set an economic growth target of 5% next year but acknowledges that internal and external conditions are likely to remain unfavorable, with continuing uncertainties such as fluctuating oil prices and foreign exchange rates, and stagnant domestic demand.
The country's biggest card lender is facing bankruptcy and millions of consumers are defaulting on credit card bills.
The government will ask firms to roll over mortgage loans coming due in 2025.
South Korea will also look at ways to help families on low incomes, reduce redundancies in the building trade, and promote new industries such as bio-technology and nano-technology.
granite3.1-dense:2b: South Korea plans to allocate 100 trillion won (approximately $96 billion) for the first six months of 2005, representing 60% of its annual budget, to stimulate economic growth and create 400,000 jobs.
The primary challenges are sluggish consumer spending and a contraction in the construction sector due to lingering effects from a credit bubble that recently burst.
The government aims to boost infrastructure development, home building, and public firm hiring to drive job creation.

South Korea targets an economic growth rate of 5% for 2005 but acknowledges potential difficulties due to unfavorable global conditions, fluctuating oil prices, foreign exchange rates, and stagnant domestic demand.
To address the construction industry's struggles, the government proposes extending mortgage loans and exploring assistance for low-income families.
The plan also includes promoting emerging industries like bio-technology and nano-technology, along with supporting small and medium-sized businesses.
Despite the government's optimism, a consultancy, 4Cast, expresses concern about the overly optimistic budget allocation.
